body:
> Resource exhausted: 

error 1 is your GPU is busy; go to nvidia-smi and kill any python process and try again ;)
error 2, perhaps this needs updated cc @AlexEMG @jeylau

RE: error 1
Interesting. I will try this now.
I wonder what else could be running... maybe it was testscript attempts that were running in the background from me trying ```pythonw``` to run it (seems like it would not handle whatever error was happening and kept silently 'closing' which probably means it didn't close the process).
^ very likely, also be sure to delete the resulting TEXT-ALEX ... folder

Hmmm. I did not see any processes labelled python in nvidia-smi. Most of the processes were things that seemed native to windows operation (which means many look like automatic start up items (see screenshot below)... i did not open skype or any other apps listed. the only thing open on purpose is chrome and anaconda powershell). But I did not want to force quit any of these PID without knowing if they were expected to be running for windows os to not complain. So instead I shutdown the computer and let it sit powered off for a bit... 1) I then re-started the computer. 2) I re-checked nvidia-smi to see if the list was reduced, but it was the same as before shutdown: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4777333/86969544-f7a15c80-c13b-11ea-8e9c-87763f4297c8.png) 2) I did not do anything else on the computer before moving to DeepLabCut directory and launching the GUI from ipython 3) loaded my test project 4) navigated to the train network tab 5) process started, but ended in same error stream as before. So there were no processes that I started on the GPU... only whatever exists from fresh computer startup. I will keep googling, but let me know if you have any other insights on this issue. here is the powershell log from the start of launch_dlc() as I loaded the project and clicked the Train Network button (after reducing display 100, save 5000, and max iters 10000). I have copied until the stream of "I tensorflow/core/common_runtime/bfc_allocator.cc:632] Chunk at" starts.
TRACEBACK

looking like CUDA is the wrong version, i.e. for TF 1.12 - 1.15 you need 10.0, not 10.2... 

also it's just not a big enough card, i.e. P4000 with ~ 8 GB card, with only 6 available, and the model is asking for 9:

> ran out of memory trying to allocate 910.00MiB.

you can:

lower `global_scale` in the train pose_cfg.yaml file, and drop the `batchsize` in pose_cfg.yaml to < 8, i.e. 2 or such...

rename.from: Errors raised on training video step

body:
Ok. Thank you. I thought that I had all of those versions sorted out after following https://www.pytorials.com/how-to-install-tensorflow-gpu-with-cuda-10-0-for-python-on-windows/
But I will work on that to try to figure out why my CUDA went from 10.0 to 10.2

I had already written the following when I saw your recent comment about CUDA and about batch size: Your most recent comment makes sense in light of what I had found/tried below (changing global_scale and batchsize parameters is A LOT more informed than what I tried below and I will try that now on my project going back to witholding cropping as I had originally -- but I think I don´t understand the impact of the training set cropping properly as per my question below):

_______what I had written while you posted the two comments above____
A little progress (followed by a question).
I found this post: https://github.com/google/seq2seq/issues/301
It sounded like the same issue arose from a memory issue in this person´s case, which made me realize that I had denied cropping option in the create training set step. I went back to the GUI and did the create training set step again, this time with default cropping. This time the training seems to be progressing through iterations (it is up to iteration 1000 now). So I guess that was my issue.

Which leads to my question (which is probably really naive). From what I could tell in my initial exploration, the cropped frames option in the training set creation leads to a bunch of images with nothing in them and many with only partial views of a single animal. How are whole animal skeletons recognized/learned (and multianimals) learned if they are never in the same image at the same time? How does the training on the cropped frames work if the cropped frames don´t contain whole images of each animal (let alone different animals together)?
Does that question make sense? I obviously don´t understand the machine learning backend and want to make sure that this is expected behavior and that I am not doing something wrong with the cropping parameters or original video files. 

RE error2 with testscript.py:
since the error occurred during tests with ResNet50 I would think this would come up with the multianimal training that I now have running from the GUI (though it has not yet). I will keep you posted. Let me know if there are further troubleshooting steps I should take for that testscript.py error.

All good Q's 

first, the testscript.py actually might not be working with 2.2beta yet; there is a specific testscript_multianimal.py you should run if you have 2.2 installed; sorry I should have caught that earlier. 

for maDLC, the cropping sounds correct :) it will learn "limbs" between connected points independent if the whole animal is shown, and hopefully in some it is. the default is 400 by 400, but you can also try larger if your GPU can tolerate that step, but it's really advised to  run the `cropandlabel`  as you did, as it's also making the network worked harder for a good solution is actually a good thing, if that makes sense ;)

**RE CUDA version with nvidia-smi:**
I found this (https://askubuntu.com/questions/1107292/nvidia-smi-shows-cuda-version-but-cuda-is-not-installed):
```Be aware that the CUDA VERSION displayed by nvidia-smi associated with newer drivers is the DRIVER API COMPATIBILITY VERSION. It does not indicate anything at all about what CUDA version is actually installed. For example: A 410.72 driver will display CUDA VERSION 10.0 even when no CUDA toolkit is installed.```

Which explains why nvidia-smi reports CUDA 10.2 even though I installed 10.0 and all of the path variables and program folders specify 10.0
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4777333/86973431-8add9080-c142-11ea-8ad6-72885b7d3997.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4777333/86973464-992bac80-c142-11ea-8d7e-927430b7cb35.png)

**HOWEVER it sounds like my issue might have been with resisting cropping, which over-requested the GPU.
 (Thank you for the information regarding my cropping question. That helps me understand more).**

**Regarding the information about ```lower global_scale in the train pose_cfg.yaml file, and drop the batchsize in pose_cfg.yaml to < 8, i.e. 2 or such...```.** Is this somethings that I should still address or does enabling cropping in the training set solve this in a better way? 
Similarly, is there still something I should change regarding the issue that the P4000 is a~ 8 GB card, with only 6 available, but the model is asking for 9? Is this something I should also change in pose_cfg.yaml so that my GPU does not get over-requested by the model in the future?

AHA! Ok. I will try testscript_multianimal.py now.
(I was waiting until testscript.py passed first before trying that one, but that makes sense that the multianimal testscript would be more relevant for 2.2b6)
i would go for the cropping step as a first line of defense to memory issues, but if they still happen you can drop global_scale and batchsize, but performance could be lower, i.e. less accurate.
i will close now since generally resolved, glad it's running!

OK. Sounds good. (So there is no setting that caps the amount of memory that the model will ask for? Is that taken care of by global_scale and batchsize?)

If anything comes up with testscript_multianimal I will open a new issue rather than confusing this one.
^ I think fine to keep posting here if another issue comes up so it's easy to ref. what was done - also thanks for tip re: Windows/CUDA!

Ok. I will add to this thread. 
I did encounter my next issue in testscript_multianimal:
This is the only thing I have found so far that seems perhaps on track is https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/24496
if  ```config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True``` is a fix, is it something that would go in the functions themselves or on my backend before running the script?
